data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[arthur] Fix error initializing threads on daemon mode

Some threads like the scheduler thread or the writer thread
were initialized before daemonizing (forking) the script.
This is a bug beacuse threads are not shared after a fork() call.

To fix it, threads must be started after the cherrypy plugin
for daemonizing is run. This plugin waits for the 'start'
event to do its fork call. Arthur server is subscribed to the
'start' events too but with a priority lower than the daemon
plugin. That is how the threads will be started after the daemon
initialization.

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[scheduler] Schedule jobs using 'sched'

This commit introduces the use of 'sched', an event scheduler
from the standard library. This allows to define 'when' jobs
will be added to a queue.

The main thread will now run sched while another thread will
listening for successful jobs to re-schedule them again usin
'sched'. The default delay is set by the WAIT_FOR_QUEUING
constant.

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.message:
[arthurd] Make configurable the server endpoint address

So far, arthurd daemon only listened to connections on
'127.0.0.1:8080' address. This change makes possible to
configure where the server will be listen for connections.

Fixes #2

data.message:
[scheduler] Avoid massive CPU usage while polling for jobs

The scheduler was set to wait 0 seconds to check whether new
jobs were ready to run. This caused a high CPU usage when it
was not needed.

The default time has been set to 0.5 seconds using the
SCHED_POLLING constant.

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[jobs] Support resuming of jobs

When a job fails, it will run again trying to resume from
the point it failed. If the limit of max retries is reached,
the job will be cancelled and sent to the queue of failed
jobs.

To track the number of times a job has been resumed,
JobResult includes a new attribute 'nresumed'.

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[scheduler] Refactorize scheduler to accept tasks

The scheduler accepts tasks as input, scheduling them into
Perceval jobs. The new scheduler supports to cancel tasks, too.

It runs a thread that will listen for finished jobs, when the
job is successful, it will be scheduled again to fetch new data;
if the result is an error, the job will be inmediately canceled.

data.message:
[tests] Add fakeredis to unit tests

The unit tests need a connection with a Redis database.
With this change, the real server is replaced by
fakeredis library to emulate the use of a server.

As ArthurWorker class inherits from rq.Worker,
the class MockArthurWorker has been created to avoid
fork call when a job is executed. The call to fork makes
fakeredis could not be used because it can only work with
threads (it uses shared memory to send messages between
workers). This error has been solved using the SimpleWorker
class from rq module.

data.message:
[setup] Improve generation of package and running tests

Some more parameters for Setup in setup.py, such as dependencies
for tests, or specific Python versions supported.
Adaption of the tests to run via setyp.py. Now, tests can be
checked by running

python setup.py test

So the schema to build packages is:

python setup.py test
python setup.py sdist
python setup.py bdist_wheel

Version in _version.py moved to first non-dev (0.1.0).
New naming schema for packages: grimoirelab-*

data.Author: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>
data.message:
Add support to run tests using setup.py file

To run user-defined commands using setup.py it is necessary
to add Command derivated classes. In this case, TestCommand
class was included to run tests.

Now all tests can be executed in two different ways:
  - Executing `$ python3 setup.py test`.
  - Running `run_tests.py` script from `tests` directory.

data.message:
[jobs] Fix 'from_date' and 'offset' reset error

So far, when a job runs in the 'update' queue and no new items
are fetched, either 'from_date' or 'offset' values are reset
to the starting values defined for the parent task (in backend_args).
This is an error because jobs in 'update' must start from the
point where the previous job ended.

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[events] Extract job listener to create a job events listener

When job was completed, the worker sent a message to notify
about whether the job finished correctly or it failed.
So far, a thread, running inside the scheduler, was listening
for those messages and scheduling new jobs. This creates
a coupling between classes and responsibilities. A listener
should only do that, and should live inside the scheduler.

This commit re-factorizes the scheduler and the listener. A new
class named `JobEventsListener`, defined in `events` module,
has been extracted from the scheduler. This class only does
the same that the old listener did. Further versions will
manage job events.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[events] Add basic job events

A new class JobEvent is introduced in this commit to send
job notifications using events. There two event types defined
so far: COMPLETED and FAILURE. Events contain information
such as the timestamp when it was generated, the job that
created it and a variable payload to store specific data.

Events can be serialized and deserialized to send them
though Redis pubsub channels.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[events] Allow job events subscription

With this patch, the event listener adds methods to subscribe
to/unsubscribe of job events. Along With the subscription,
a handler to process the events must be provided.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[jobs] Generate items using BackendItemsGenerator

The class 'BackendItemsGenerator' from 'perceval' package
provides an easy way to generate items and to obtain a
summary with the results while fetching process is running.

This commit replaces the call to the alternative methods
'fetch' and 'fetch_from_archive' that are deprecated and
removed soon.

This is the first steep needed to use the summary generated
by Perceval.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[jobs] Refactor 'metadata' decorator

The decorator 'metadata' has been refactored and moved to
the class PercevalJob. Now it is a private method called
when items are generated inside the method 'run'.

This change was needed because the method 'execute' was
decorated by this function but it was replaced for a method
that creates an items generator.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.Author: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[jobs] Replace job result object by Perceval summary

Some information related to the progress of a job was
stored within JobResult. Since Perceval provides 'Summary'
objects for each fetch process, this information is
redundant.

This commit replaces this information by the one provided
by Perceval, which is more accurated and completed. For
example, it stores the number of items generated and skipped;
the UUID of last item generated; max and min dates of the
items and so on.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

data.Author: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>
data.message:
[scheduler] Remove 'arthur' prefix and task id from job ids schema

The new schema for job ids consists on a single hash, generated
using the `uuid` module. The former schema was:
`arthur-<task_id>-hash`.

The `arthur-` prefix was set in the past to identify jobs coming
from different sources (not from `arthur`). By removing this
prefix the job ids are now simpler, as the origin of the job
could be included as meta-data instead of a part of the job id.

The `task_id` parameter came from the task triggering the job.
By removing this section, we are avoiding future problems as this
field could contain whitespaces or other unusual characters.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>
